newsitem.title: JAPAN: Sony revives hope for rally in high-tech shares.
newsitem.headline: Sony revives hope for rally in high-tech shares.

text.p: Shares in Sony Corp shot to an all-time high of 10,000 yen on Friday, rekindling hopes that the popular stock can pull up other high technology issues, and the entire Japanese stock market.

"Sony is the leader of the high-tech pack," said Noboru Yorita, general manager at Tachibana Securities. "If the rally continues, other high-tech favourites such as TDK Corp and Kyocera Corp, whose share prices are a step behind Sony's, may be towed to similar heights."

Yasuo Ueki, Nikko Securities general manager, echoed this view. "In recent sessions, investors were lost as fluctuations in the yen distorted trade direction," he said. "But with the return of the high-techs, it will make it easier for investors to figure out what will lead in the upcoming June market."
June is considered a particularly auspicious month for Japanese stocks. Last year, the Nikkei average hit its highs for the year in June.

Sony defied the wobbly Nikkei benchmark for most of the day on Friday, before buckling under the weight of profit-taking just ahead of the close to end 30 yen lower at 9,810 yen, on turnover of 2.12 million shares.
The Nikkei average fell 243.42 points, or 1.20 percent, to settle at 20,068.81.

"Turnover (in Sony shares) was fairly large and it didn't fall too hard despite profit-taking after its rise to 10,000, which means that there is still quite a lot of interest," a trader at a foreign brokerage said.

The Tokyo market took its cues from activity overnight in London, where Sony and other high-technology shares such as Hitachi Ltd flourished on the back of a weaker yen and recent robust earnings reports.
Brokers said the weaker yen also encouraged domestic and foreign investors in Tokyo, which pushed shares in Sony, a blue-chip exporter, to its new record high.
A strong dollar relative to the yen is bullish for exporters, as it makes prices of Japanese exports more competitive overseas.
The dollar traded above 116 yen on Friday in Tokyo, exceeding the 115 yen-per-dollar rate that Sony used to calculate its earnings forecast for the 1997/98 business year ending next March.
Brokers said Sony shares could retrace in the near term but would eventually pick up where they left off, backed by the firm's healthy earnings and strong prospects.
Sony recently announced record group net profits for the business year to March 31, 1997 of 139.46 billion yen ($1.20 billion), a 2.6-fold rise from the previous year.
The firm, which is moving aggressively into new areas like digital satellite broadcasting, said it expects further growth to 160 billion yen ($1.37 billion) in the current year.
High-tech issues TDK Corp and Kyocera are also closing in on the 10,000-yen mark, and market sources said Sony's strength may eventually pull them up to that level.
TDK Corp rose as high as 9,150 yen on Friday, but slid to close 110 yen lower at 8,940. The shares hit a record high of 9,480 earlier this month.
Kyocera also retraced on Friday after setting a new 1997 high of 8,560 yen. The stock closed at 8,390, up 90 yen.
